The required parameters are listed in the Standards of Identity for each product. - The operator should keep the lab results on file in the facility (and should re-test if recipe changes) Not applicable | | - Pickles, salsas and sauces are frequently acidified foods. These are subject to federal regulation if they are a sealed, shelf-stable product - See [Processing Guidance #5](/oha/PH/HEALTHYENVIRONMENTS/FOODSAFETY/Documents/5%20acidifiedfoods.pdf) - If the product is a shelf-stable acidified food, a license by Oregon Department of Agriculture will be required instead of a variance from OHA. BBQ Sauces, Marinades, Dressings Special Process: Reduced Oxygen Packaging - Bottling Sauces for Retail Sale [See Fact Sheet #22](/oha/PH/HEALTHYENVIRONMENTS/FOODSAFETY/Documents/FactSheet22SaucesDressings.pdf) 1) Unsealed bottles, held at 41F with 7day datemark and properly labeled 2) Unsealed bottles, extended shelf life under refrigeration: a. Provide pH sample results of product from an approved food testing lab and have a water activity and pH that demonstrate the product to be non-potentially hazardous b. Operator must keep all product under refrigeration and label 'Keep Refrigerated' c. Operator must submit sample to lab to determine shelf life of product d. Product must be properly labeled for retail sale Not applicable | | - Any hermetically sealed, shelf stable product - See [Processing Guidance #5](/oha/PH/HEALTHYENVIRONMENTS/FOODSAFETY/Documents/5%20acidifiedfoods.pdf) - If the product is a shelf-stable acidified food, a license by Oregon Department of Agriculture will be required instead of a variance from OHA.
